title.narrative: Prevention+ Uganda

description.narrative: Prevention+ aims to address gender inequality by promoting masculinities based on equality, non-violence and care-giving, and by focusing on boys and men, and girls and women, as agents of change. The long term objectives of this five-year program are to contribute to a gender just society which is free of gender-based violence (GBV). Prevention+ aims to transform social norms that drive GBV, and contribute to related changes in legislation, policies and practices of governments and other service providers. Rutgers, Promundo, and Sonke Gender Justice, along with local partners, will work with institutions and male and female adolescents and adults across Indonesia, Pakistan, Uganda, Rwanda and selected Mena countries. Women's rights organizations are essential partners of this program to support activities and advocate for change. The MenEngage Alliance will further promote Prevention+ objectives internationally through its network and policy advocacy. The program is evidence-based; it has been developed on the basis of research findings that show that well-designed gender-transformative programs with both sexes of different age groups are highly effective in order to underpin the positive transformation of rigid gender norms and contribute to a society free of GBV. Prevention+ is funded by the Government of the Netherlands

title.narrative: Output reporting Prevention+ Uganda
Result area 1: OUTCOME- Young) men and women have more gender just attitudes and behavior

description.narrative: Result Area 1: (Young) men and women have violence free and gender equal relationships

title.narrative: 1.4 Improved ability of % of participating (young) men to cope with problems and to control their aggression and frustration (e.g. reducing alcohol abuse)

description.narrative: Our outcome measurement plan included using pre and post-test surveys to assess ability to cope with problems & to control aggression at baseline and end line of program interventions.

comment.narrative: We found that improved ability of participating (young) men to cope with problems and control aggression / frustration improved from 87/253 (34%) at baseline to 138/200 (69%) at end line. Copying mechanisms and controlling aggression among females improved from 72/205 (35%) to 93/130 (72%) between baseline and end line as compared to males whose copying mechanisms improved from 15/47 (32%) at baseline to 45/70 (64%) at end line.

title.narrative: 1.2 Improved communication skills within % of the participating couples

description.narrative: Our outcome measurement plan included using pre and post-test surveys to assess communication skills within participating couples at baseline and end line of program interventions.

comment.narrative: Participating couples improved their communication skills by 33% during the project interventions i.e. from a proportion of 88/253 participants (35%) at baseline to a proportion of 136/200 participants (68%) at end line. There was no significant difference in the improvement of communication skills between females and males.

title.narrative: 1.5 Reduced levels of intimate partner violence among % of participants

description.narrative: Our outcome measurement plan included using pre and post-test surveys to assess reduced levels of intimate partner violence a at baseline and end line of program interventions.

comment.narrative: Reporting reduced levels of IPV increased by 26% between baseline and end-line. Participants who reported reduced levels of IPV was 132/253 (52%) at baseline compared to 156/200 (78%) at end-line. Among females, reporting reduced levels of IPV increased by 28% i.e. from 110/205 (54%) at baseline to 107/130 (82%) at end line. Among males, reporting reduced levels of IPV increased by 25% i.e. from 21/47 (45%) at baseline to 49/70 (70%) at end-line.

title.narrative: 1.3 % participating (young) men and women who do not believe intimate partner violence is acceptable

description.narrative: Our outcome measurement plan included using pre and post-test surveys to assess who do not believe in intimate partner violence at baseline and end line of program interventions.

comment.narrative: The proportion of (young) men and women who do not believe that intimate partner violence is acceptable increased by 12% i.e. from a proportion of 131/253 participants (52%) at baseline to a proportion of 128/200 (64%) at end line. The increase in females who do no believe that IPV was acceptable was 8% from 109/205 (53%) at baseline to 79/130 (61%) at end line. The proportion of males who do not believe that IPV was acceptable increased by 23 % i.e. from 22/47 (47%) at baseline to 49/70 (70%) at end line

title.narrative: 1.1 % of participating (young) men and women have more positive attitudes, including acceptance of positive masculinities (including equitable, non-violent, care giving) and of women’s political and economic participation

description.narrative: Our outcome measurement plan included using pre and post-test surveys to assess attitudes and behaviour at baseline and end line of program interventions.

comment.narrative: We found that equitable attitudes, non-violent and caregiving improved by 18% i.e. from a proportion of 163/253 participants (64%) at baseline to a proportion of 164/200 participants (82%) at end line. Among females, equitable attitudes improved by 27% i.e. from a proportion of 141/205 (69%) at baseline to a proportion of 125/130 (96%) at end-line compared to male counterparts whose equitable attitudes improved by 11% i.e. from a proportion of 21/47 (45%) at baseline to a proportion of 38/70 (56%) at end-line.

title.narrative: 1.6 % of (young) men and women report positive changes towards more equitable decision-making patterns (e.g. on household economics)

description.narrative: The ETR and outcome measurement plan FGDs were used to assess performance under this indicator.

comment.narrative: Quote 'my partner now involves me in decision making and resource allocation. We now have monthly meetings to plan with our children (female adults Arua district). Quote 'the training sessions increased our love, we now respect each others decisions and also my partner has improved his care for our children. (male adult FGD Bushenyi)

title.narrative: Result area 2: OUTCOME- Increased supportive norms to prevent GBV and promote gender justice

description.narrative: Result Area 2: Communities hold equitable gender norms and prevent GBV

title.narrative: 2.1 Increased positive notions of manhood (equitable, non-violent and caring) among (young) men and women in the targeted communities

description.narrative: Outcome measurement plan FGDs for assessing community perception on gender-equitable norms and prevention of GBV that was conducted among Women groups, Male action groups, and Champions.

comment.narrative: On ensuring that communities hold equitable gender norms and prevent GBV, the output performance level was 157% at end term compared to 70.5% at mid term. The ETR observed that there were significant increase in positive notions of manhood (equitable, non-violent and caring) among (young) men and women in the targeted communities. All female FGDs reported improvement in caring by their male spouses

title.narrative: 2.2 Positive change within the targeted communities intervening in GBV cases and/or supporting GBV survivors

description.narrative: ETR investigated the willingness of community participants to support GBV survivors

comment.narrative: The ETR observed significant positive changes among targeted communities where identification, reporting and intervening in GBV cases and/or supporting GBV survivors. However, support to GBV survivors was not sufficient given the nature of training content provided to the community facilitators which, according to some of them, lacked a strong component of ongoing psychosocial support. This view was also shared by one of the district probation officers; “There is need to now focus on providing psychosocial support to the victims on an ongoing basis….previously, the focus has been on punishing the perpetrators”

title.narrative: Result area 3: OUTCOME- More CSOs and relevant public sectors have institutionalized gender transformative approaches.

description.narrative: Result Area 3: Public institutions & civil society organisations have institutionalised gender transformative approaches and promote gender justice

title.narrative: 3.4 Improved referral and/or response mechanisms for survivors of GBV

description.narrative: We've used quarterly review and planning meetings under the GBV networks to monitor progress on referral and response mechanisms.

comment.narrative: 'The project has supported the establishment of GBV prevention networks. Consequently, the networks have improved referral and response mechanisms for GBV survivors in the 3 projects. GBV prevention networks are active in all project sites. We work with village health teams (VHTs) and trained community facilitators on cases identification, counselling and referral for further management to other government facilities. After training the duty bearers e.g. Police, health workers and probation and welfare officers in GTA , we have seen an improved working relationships and referral mechanism.

title.narrative: 3.6 Targeted institutions/ CSOs integrate gender transformative approaches in services offered

description.narrative: Quarterly meetings were done to enable participating CSOs / institutions to share updates on the adoption of GTA in their programmes. The ETR assessed this indicator through key informant interviews to establish the level of achievement under this outcome.

comment.narrative: •Prevention+ program has trained staff from institutions and CSOs in GTA. After training, institutions were expected to review their policies or operations and find a way of integrating GTA messages. Mid-term results showed that Muslim leaders have introduced Program P messages (e.g on positive parenting ) into their sermons. Further, religious leaders have integrated positive parenting into couple counseling and guidance. Muni University reviewed the university policies to assess entry point to integrate GTA. FIDA has integrated fatherhood into legal counseling. •The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) in Arua, accepted to join the GBV network. The Agency participated in the formulation of Local Action Plan (LAP) that is gender transformative in nature, took it up and shared it (LAP) with the national SGBV taskforce as best practice for emulation by other refugee host district. •The project has built capacity of religious institutions. For example Madi and West Nile Diocese (Arua district) through prevention+ built capacity of 5 pastors who are active in their parishes and having community dialogues, contextualized Bible studies and other sessions on gender transformation and SGBV. The diocese has also reviewed church structures (Women’s union and Father’s union) and came up with Family Life Desk as a way of institutionalising GTA. •Arua Prisons (female wing) conducts monthly Focus Group Discussions (FGDs) with female inmates on Gender equality, Human rights and non-violence. 2 female prison staff that trained in Program P have rolled out the program among the female inmates. A drama group was formed and staged performance during 16 days of Activism campaign. •An institution for child protection in Arua district (ANPPCAN Uganda Chapter), benefited from Prevention+ project. 2 staff who trained in program P have integrated it in their capacity building trainings (Training curriculum for parents, Caretakers and Paralegals in child protection). •FIDA-Uganda (Kapchorwa), an organization that empowers women to seek for justice in courts of law, through Prevention+ adapted the use of male role models as mediators during sessions which has attracted other men to see for legal services in this centre. •Elgon radio station media centre (Kapchorwa), with support from Prevention+ airs out gender-transformative messages to public. The media centre ensures gender balance in the panelists (male & female) used to pass or broadcast information. Faith leaders in 3 districts reviewed religious sermons using GTA lenses e.g. during pre-marital counseling by pastors & Sheikhs/ Imams, Uganda Police in Arua adopted GTA e.g. by recruiting both male and female staff under Child and Family Protection unit.

title.narrative: 3.5 Targeted institutions have developed and/or implemented more favourable policies, budgets, protocols or guidelines

description.narrative: We used quarterly network review and feedback meetings to assess the development of policies, budgets and guidelines, and the signing of MOU. During ETR, we measured this indicator using KII

comment.narrative: Arua GBV Network developed bi-annual news letter which highlights guidelines for the network. Bushenyi and Arua District Local Government developed local action plan to address GBV using GTA lens that has been embraced by other CSOs and institutions in the district. In Kapchorwa, FIDA Uganda, Action Aid and Uganda Human Rights Commission developed guidelines that support male involvement in women empowerment programmes.

title.narrative: Result area 3: OUTCOME- Improved quality of GBV programming and services provided to (young) women and men within the public and CSO sector

description.narrative: Result Area 3: Public institutions & civil society organisations have institutionalised gender transformative approaches and promote gender justice

title.narrative: 3.3 Increased comfort and skills in trained government and CSO staff in working with (young) men to prevent GBV

description.narrative: We used pre& post test surveys to assess whether gov't & CSO trained staff improved skills for preventing GBV.

comment.narrative: In-depth interviews with CSOs and public partners indicated, all interviewed staff under the program who were interviewed expressed increased comfort in working with (young) men to prevent GBV. There was improved knowledge among CSOs & government staff on working with men and boys to prevent GBV. Their skills had been enhanced by the training from 77% at baseline to 99% at end line. .

title.narrative: 3.2 More favourable attitudes towards engaging (young) men in GBV prevention among trained government and CSO staff.

description.narrative: Pre and Post-test surveys were conducted among these gov't & CSO staff before and after the week-long training. We also assessed this indicator using FGDs during End Term Review

comment.narrative: There were favorable changes in attitudes towards engaging (young) men in GBV prevention among trained government and CSO staff. This change was re-echoed in all FGDs of participating community representatives

title.narrative: 3.1 More favourable attitudes towards gender equity among % of trained government and CSO staff.

description.narrative: We used pre and post-test surveys during the trainings. We also used KII during ETR to measure this indicator

comment.narrative: In-depth interviews with CSOs and public partners indicated, all interviewed staff under the program who were interviewed expressed a positive change in attitudes towards gender equality. At the end line, results of the pre and post-test surveys indicated that 100% of all trained Government and CSO staff had favorable attitudes towards gender equity. In addition, all the KII of the ETR who had received training, demonstrated favorable attitudes towards gender equity.

title.narrative: Result area 4: OUTCOME- Targeted policy and law makers, donors or development partners display commitment to engage (young) men in GBV prevention and gender transformative approaches

description.narrative: Result Area 4: Enabling environment - at national and international level - to prevent GBV by engaging boys and men and to support gender justice

title.narrative: 4.4 # of targeted policy- and law-makers, donors or development partners who make or sign-on to official commitments (statements, agreements) on the need to engage (young) men in GBV prevention and gender justice

description.narrative: Used quarterly and bi-annual reports. The ETR assessed this indicator through key informant interviews and documents review to establish the level of achievement under this outcome

comment.narrative: Overall, 132 policy and law makers, donors or development partners signed on to official commitments on the need to engage young men in GBV prevention & gender justice.

title.narrative: 4.3 # of targeted policy- and law-makers, donors or development partners who include language on the need to engage (young) men in GBV prevention in public speeches, existing communications, or public facing/official documents

description.narrative: We measured this indicator by routinely monitoring policy and law-makers, donors, and development partners that we engage through trainings, events such as the commemoration of national and international days, and those with whom we engage in advocacy work during which they include language in their speeches, communication or sign official documents committing to engage young men in GBV prevention and GTA.

comment.narrative: There was improved commitment by targeted policy- and law-makers, donors or development partners who supported the GBV response through public speeches, existing communications, or public facing/official documents. Some examples include; commitment in signing the Local Action Plans to implement GBV prevention interventions, signing Local Ordinances among others. Overall, 226 policy and law makers included language on the need to engage men and boys in GBV prevention & response in public speeches, existing documents & official documents.

title.narrative: Result area 4:OUTCOME-Increased awareness, support, capacity, collaboration and uptake of gender transformative approaches to engage (young) men and women in GBV prevention amongst networks, movements and organisations

description.narrative: Result Area 4: Enabling environment - at national and international level - to prevent GBV by engaging boys and men and to support gender justice

title.narrative: 4.2 Targeted networks, movements, and organisations have strengthened capacity and collaboration in advocating for gender justice and GBV prevention

description.narrative: The indicator was measured using training and other programme reports. We measured this change during ETR through KII and document review.

comment.narrative: In all the project implementing districts, the project formed strong GBV prevention and gender justice promotion networks, and have since strengthened capacity and collaboration in advocating for gender justice and GBV prevention.

title.narrative: 4.1 # of representatives from targeted networks, movements, and organisations who sign-on to official committments on gender justice and GBV prevention or include language on engaging (young) men and boys in GBV prevention in public speeches, existing campaigns and communications

description.narrative: We monitored quarterly and bi-annually the number of representatives from networks and organizations who sign on to official commitments on GJ and GBV prevention or include language on engaging men & boys in GBV prevention campaigns

comment.narrative: A total of 106 representatives or members from networks & organisations signed on to official commitments on gender justice and GBV prevention or included language on engaging young men & boys in GBV prevention in speeches and campaigns.

title.narrative: Result area 4: OUTCOME-Development and/or implementation of laws, policies, budgets and guidelines for engaging (young) men in GBV prevention and gender transformative approaches

description.narrative: Result Area 4: Enabling environment - at national and international level - to prevent GBV by engaging boys and men and to support gender justice

title.narrative: 4.5 # international, national and sub-national policy, laws, budgets and guidelines developed and/or implemented on engaging (young) men in GBV prevention or promoting gender justice

description.narrative: We used bi-annual and annual reports. The ETR assessed this indicator through key informant interviews to establish the level of achievement.

comment.narrative: It was observed that there was significant program contribution towards development of district level ordinances, budgets, work plans; and national level policies and guidelines and costed plans. Overall 10 national and sub-national policy, laws, budgets and guidelines were developed or implemented on engaging young men in GBV prevention or promoting gender justice.

title.narrative: Result area 5: OUTCOME- Strengthened capacity of civil society to advance women’s rights and gender equality.

description.narrative: Result Area 5: Capacity of civil society organisations strengthened for women’s rights and gender equality

title.narrative: 5.1 CSO staff have strengthened capacity to advance women’s rights and gender equality
Result area 5: OUTPUT - CSO staff are strengthened through capacity building activities for women's rights and gender equality
5a # of civil society organisations with stronger capacity to advance women's rights and gender equality

Result area 1: OUTPUT- (Young) men and women participate in (group) programmes improving skills, knowledge, attitudes and behavior in GBV and gender justice

1.b # (young) men and women involved in various discussions, support, and/ or counselling groups focused on healthy relationships, prevention/ ending of SGBV, parenting and fatherhood, economic empowerment and gender equality
1.a community facilitators trained to implement the programmatic interventions
Result area 1: OUTPUT- (Young) men and women have access to information and education concerning GBV, parenting, and gender justice

1.c # education materials produced that address GBV and/or gender justice

Result area 3: OUTPUT- Government and CSO staff trained and sensitized in gender transformative approaches to prevent GBV
3.b # master trainers who have been trained in gender transformative approaches to prevent GBV

Result area 4: OUTPUT- Targeted networks, movements and organisations collaborate on engaging (young) men in GBV prevention and gender justice
4.c # country and # global joint advocacy strategies developed on gender transformative approaches to prevent GBV and gender justice

4.f # of media mentions on the need to engage (young) men in GBV prevention and gender justice through different channels (radio, TV, print)
